Practicising Feminine فعل And اسم موصول

words.w:
In this lesson we learn:

1. The plural of nouns and adjectives. In English adjectives have no plural form. We say: "good man" and "good men". But in Arabic even adjectives have plural forms.

2. In English we have two kinds of plural form: (1) Sound (2) Broken 
In the sound plural the word retains its original form e.g. book->books, pen->pens.

In the broken plural the original form of the word is changed to a great extent, e.g. man->men, women->women

In Arabic we have these two kinds of plural forms: sound and broken.
The sound plural is either masculine or feminine. The sound masculine plural has "-uuna" ending. e.g.
In sound feminine plural has "aat-u-n" ending. e.g.

Note that in this plural form, the singular has short "a" before the "t" (muslimat-u-n), and the "t" is round (ة), whereas in the plural the "a" is long(muslimaat-u-n), and the "t" is open (ت) 

 The broken plural: There are more than twenty patterns of the broken plural. Some are given here. Unlike in English, the broken plural is very widely used in Arabic. These are:
Note:We know that noun ends with single damma is a diptote (A diptote is a noun that reflects the nominative case with the ضمة vowel, and both accusative and genitive cases with the فتحة vowel).

The student is advised to learn the plural form of every new noun and adjectives he learns.

3. The plural of هَذَا and هَذِهِ is هَؤُلَاءِ e.g.

Note that هَؤُلَاءِ is mostly used with human beings. Its use to refer to non-human beings is rare.

4. The plural of هُوَ is هُمْ. Unlike the singular هُوَ the plural هُوَ is used to refer only to human beings, e.g.
The plural of هُ(his) is هُمْ(their), e.g.
Their father is a famous merchant.
Note that the words for "they" and "their" have the same form (هُمْ).
